title: 1963–64 Southern Football League
text:
The 1963–64 <a href="Southern%20Football%20League">Southern Football League</a> season was the 61st in the history of the league, an English <a href="Association%20football">football</a> competition.
<a href="Yeovil%20Town%20F.C.">Yeovil Town</a> won the championship, whilst <a href="Cheltenham%20Town%20F.C.">Cheltenham Town</a>, <a href="Folkestone%20Town%20F.C.">Folkestone Town</a>, <a href="King%27s%20Lynn%20F.C.">King's Lynn</a> and <a href="Tonbridge%20F.C.">Tonbridge</a> were all promoted to the Premier Division. Seven Southern League clubs applied to join <a href="the%20Football%20League">the Football League</a> at the end of the season, but none were successful.
Premier Division.
The Premier Division consisted of 22 clubs, including 18 clubs from the <a href="1962%E2%80%9363%20Southern%20Football%20League%23Premier%20Division">previous season</a> and four new clubs, promoted from Division One:
Also, Bexleyheath & Welling changed name to <a href="Bexley%20United%20F.C.">Bexley United</a>.
League table.
<onlyinclude></onlyinclude>
Division One.
Division One consisted of 22 clubs, including 16 clubs from the <a href="1962%E2%80%9363%20Southern%20Football%20League%23Division%20One">previous season</a> and six new clubs:
Also, Tunbridge Wells United changed name to <a href="Tunbridge%20Wells%20F.C.">Tunbridge Wells Rangers</a>.
At the end of the season, <a href="Hillingdon%20Borough%20F.C.">Yiewsley</a> changed name to Hillingdon Borough, while <a href="F.C.%20Clacton">Clacton Town</a> switched to the <a href="Eastern%20Counties%20Football%20League">Eastern Football League</a>.
League table.
<onlyinclude></onlyinclude>
Football League elections.
Alongside the four League clubs facing re-election, a total of 13 non-League clubs applied for election, including seven Southern League clubs. All four League clubs were re-elected.
